description.short: Measures vulnerability to emotional resistance to security updates based on attachment relationships with familiar legacy systems
description.context: Organizations develop emotional bonds with legacy systems that extend beyond functional utility, creating psychological resistance to security upgrades and replacements. This attachment manifests when teams treat outdated systems as 'too important to change' despite known vulnerabilities, leading to extended attack windows and increased breach risk. Legacy system attachment creates blind spots where security teams avoid implementing controls on 'trusted' systems, while threat actors specifically target these outdated, under-protected assets.
description.impact: Organizations with legacy attachment experience extended support contracts for systems past vendor security lifecycle, special exemptions for legacy systems in security policies, and delayed or avoided system replacement projects despite budget availability. Historical incidents include the 2017 WannaCry ransomware that specifically targeted Windows XP systems organizations kept operational past Microsoft's support end, and industrial control systems kept operational despite security vulnerabilities due to operational attachment.
description.psychological_basis: Attachment to legacy systems represents a complex psychological phenomenon rooted in object relations theory and transitional object concepts. The core mechanism involves the formation of emotional bonds with technological systems that transcend their functional utility, creating a psychological dependency that mirrors early attachment patterns described by Bowlby (1969). Winnicott (1971) described how legacy systems function as organizational transitional objects - neither purely functional tools nor purely symbolic representations, but existing in a psychological space that provides comfort and security. The attachment process involves familiarity bias (known systems feel safer regardless of objective security posture), loss aversion (the psychological pain of losing familiar systems outweighs potential gains from upgrades with a 2-3x psychological cost differential per Kahneman & Tversky 1979), and identity integration (the legacy system becomes part of organizational or personal identity). fMRI studies show familiar technologies activate reward pathways in the brain similar to social attachment bonds, with the amygdala showing reduced threat response to familiar systems even when objective security risks are present.

green.label: Low Vulnerability - Resilient
green.description: Organization has documented lifecycle management with automatic replacement triggers when vendor support ends. No systems run past security support lifecycle for more than 6 months. Legacy systems follow same security policies as modern systems. Multiple staff trained on each critical system.

yellow.label: Moderate Vulnerability - Developing
yellow.description: Some systems run past vendor support but with compensating controls and documented risk acceptance. Occasional exemptions from security policies with formal approval process. Timeline for replacements typically 12-18 months from decision. Some knowledge concentration but succession planning in place.

red.label: High Vulnerability - Critical
red.description: Multiple systems running years past vendor security support. Regular exemptions from security policies without formal risk assessment. Strong organizational resistance to legacy system changes. Critical systems dependent on single individuals. No defined replacement timelines or processes.

system_age_past_support.calculation: Days/months/years since vendor security support ended
system_age_past_support.query: SELECT system_id, DATEDIFF(NOW(), vendor_support_end_date) as days_past_support FROM asset_inventory WHERE vendor_support_end_date < NOW() ORDER BY days_past_support DESC

exemption_frequency.calculation: Count of security policy exemptions for legacy systems
exemption_frequency.query: SELECT COUNT(*) as exemption_count FROM policy_exemptions WHERE system_id IN (SELECT system_id FROM legacy_systems) AND exemption_date > NOW() - INTERVAL '6 months'

replacement_delay.calculation: Time from replacement decision to deployment
replacement_delay.query: SELECT AVG(DATEDIFF(deployment_date, decision_date)) as avg_replacement_delay FROM system_replacements WHERE status='completed' AND deployment_date > NOW() - INTERVAL '2 years'

sections.title: QUICK ASSESSMENT

items.title: End-of-Life System Inventory
items.question: How many systems in your IT environment are currently running past their vendor's official security support lifecycle? Please provide specific examples of your oldest systems still in production.

options.label: No systems running past security support lifecycle for more than 6 months
Some systems past vendor support (6-18 months) with documented compensating controls
Multiple systems running years past vendor security support without compensating controls

items.evidence_required: Current asset inventory showing support lifecycle status, examples of oldest systems in production
items.soc_mapping: system_age_past_support metric from asset management system

items.title: System Replacement Timeline
items.question: What is your standard timeline for replacing systems when vendors end security support? Walk us through your most recent system replacement project and how long it took from decision to deployment.

options.label: Documented lifecycle management with automatic replacement triggers; systems replaced within 6-12 months of support ending
Replacement planning exists; typically 12-18 months from decision to deployment
No defined replacement timelines; projects frequently delayed or indefinitely postponed

items.evidence_required: Recent replacement project timeline, replacement planning documents
items.soc_mapping: replacement_delay metric from system replacement tracking

items.title: Security Policy Exemptions
items.question: How often do legacy systems receive exemptions from your standard security policies (patching schedules, monitoring requirements, access controls)? Give us a recent example where you made such an exemption and why.

options.label: Legacy systems follow same security policies as modern systems; no special exemptions
Occasional exemptions with formal approval process and documented risk acceptance
Regular exemptions from security policies without formal risk assessment or documentation

items.evidence_required: Security policy exemption logs, recent exemption approval with justification
items.soc_mapping: exemption_frequency from policy exemption tracking system

items.title: Organizational Change Resistance
items.question: What happens when your security team proposes changes or replacements for critical legacy systems? Describe the typical organizational response and decision-making process.

options.label: Organization supports necessary security changes; structured decision process with reasonable timelines
Mixed responses; some resistance but ultimately security changes are implemented
Strong organizational resistance to legacy system changes; defensive responses to security proposals

items.evidence_required: Recent legacy system change proposal and organizational response, decision-making process documentation

items.title: Knowledge Concentration Risk
items.question: How do you handle situations where only one or two people understand how to maintain a legacy system? Tell us about a specific system where you have this knowledge concentration risk.

options.label: Multiple staff trained on each critical system; documented succession planning and knowledge transfer
Some knowledge concentration but active succession planning and documentation efforts
Critical systems dependent on single individuals; no knowledge transfer or documentation programs

items.evidence_required: System documentation status, cross-training records, specific example of knowledge concentration
items.soc_mapping: single_point_of_failure count from knowledge management system

items.title: Budget Allocation Patterns
items.question: What percentage of your IT budget currently goes toward maintaining legacy systems versus investing in replacements? Provide examples of recent budget decisions between legacy maintenance and new system acquisition.

options.label: Budget prioritizes replacement investment; less than 30% allocated to legacy maintenance
Balanced allocation between maintenance and replacement; 30-50% to legacy maintenance
Majority of budget to legacy maintenance; more than 50% with limited replacement investment

items.evidence_required: Budget allocation documentation, recent budget decision examples
items.soc_mapping: legacy_maintenance_cost vs replacement_investment ratio from budget system

items.title: Legacy System Security Incidents
items.question: When you experience security incidents or vulnerabilities on legacy systems, how does your organization typically respond? Give us an example of a recent legacy system security issue and how it was resolved.

options.label: Security incidents trigger immediate replacement planning; enhanced monitoring and compensating controls deployed
Incidents addressed through patches or workarounds; some discussion of replacement but not prioritized
Defensive responses minimizing incident significance; continued operation without security improvements or replacement planning

items.evidence_required: Recent legacy system security incident example and resolution documentation
items.soc_mapping: legacy_system_incidents and resolution_type from incident tracking

sections.instructions: Select ONE option for each question. Each answer contributes to the weighted final score. Evidence should be documented for audit trail.

items.text: Walk me through your current asset inventory. Which systems are your oldest, and how long have they been running past their vendor security support lifecycle?

scoring_guidance.green: Complete inventory with lifecycle tracking; no systems past support or brief (under 6 months) with documented compensating controls
scoring_guidance.yellow: Some systems past support (6-18 months); inventory exists but lifecycle tracking inconsistent
scoring_guidance.red: Multiple systems years past support; no comprehensive inventory or lifecycle tracking

followups.text: Tell me about your oldest system still in production. Why is it still running?
How do you track when vendor security support ends for your systems? Is this automated?

items.text: Describe your most recent system replacement project. What triggered the decision, and how long did it take from decision to deployment?

scoring_guidance.green: Recent replacement completed within 6-12 months; clear trigger criteria and structured process
scoring_guidance.yellow: Replacement took 12-18 months; some delays but eventually completed
scoring_guidance.red: No recent replacements, or projects taking years with multiple delays and resistance

followups.text: What obstacles or delays did you encounter during the replacement process?
How did stakeholders react when the replacement was first proposed?

items.text: How are legacy systems treated differently from modern systems in your security policies? Give me specific examples of exemptions or special handling.

scoring_guidance.green: No special exemptions; legacy systems held to same standards with compensating controls where needed
scoring_guidance.yellow: Some exemptions exist but with formal approval process and documented risk acceptance
scoring_guidance.red: Regular exemptions without formal process; legacy systems treated as 'too important to apply normal controls'

followups.text: Walk me through a recent exemption request. Who approved it and what was the justification?
How often are these exemptions reviewed or renewed?

items.text: Tell me about a recent security incident or vulnerability affecting a legacy system. How did the organization respond?

scoring_guidance.green: Incident triggered rapid response with compensating controls or accelerated replacement planning
scoring_guidance.yellow: Incident addressed through patches or workarounds; minimal impact on replacement timeline
scoring_guidance.red: Defensive minimization of incident; continued operation without security improvements

followups.text: Did the incident lead to any changes in how you manage that legacy system?
How did leadership respond when they learned about the vulnerability?

items.text: When your security team proposes replacing or significantly changing a critical legacy system, what typically happens? Walk me through a specific example.

scoring_guidance.green: Structured evaluation process; security concerns drive decisions with reasonable stakeholder engagement
scoring_guidance.yellow: Mixed responses; some resistance but proposals eventually move forward
scoring_guidance.red: Strong defensive reactions; emotional language; proposals blocked or indefinitely delayed

followups.text: What language do people use when discussing legacy systems? Do you hear phrases like 'it's always worked' or 'we can't afford to lose it'?
How do stakeholders react to security assessments of legacy systems?

items.text: How is knowledge distributed for your critical legacy systems? Are there systems that only one or two people understand?

scoring_guidance.green: Multiple staff trained on each critical system; active knowledge transfer and documentation programs
scoring_guidance.yellow: Some knowledge concentration recognized; documentation efforts underway but incomplete
scoring_guidance.red: Critical dependency on single individuals; minimal documentation; 'tribal knowledge' culture

followups.text: Give me an example of a system where knowledge is concentrated. What happens when that person is unavailable?
What efforts have you made to document or cross-train on legacy systems?

items.text: How does your organization allocate budget between maintaining legacy systems versus investing in replacements? What drives those decisions?

scoring_guidance.green: Strategic allocation favoring replacement; maintenance costs tracked and used to justify modernization
scoring_guidance.yellow: Balanced allocation; awareness of maintenance costs but limited replacement budget
scoring_guidance.red: Majority of budget to legacy maintenance; replacement proposals consistently rejected due to 'costs'

followups.text: Show me a recent budget decision between extending legacy support versus investing in replacement.
How do you calculate and communicate the total cost of legacy system ownership?

solutions.title: Automated Lifecycle Tracking System
solutions.description: Implement asset management tools that automatically flag systems approaching end-of-support dates with mandatory replacement planning triggers
solutions.implementation: Deploy asset management system with vendor support lifecycle database. Configure automatic alerts 18 months before support ends. Implement mandatory replacement planning workflow triggered when systems approach end-of-support. Generate executive dashboard showing security support status across all systems. Create escalation process to executive level when systems run past support lifecycle without approved exception.
solutions.technical_controls: Asset management CMDB integration, vendor support date tracking, automated alerting system, executive dashboard

solutions.title: Legacy System Security Isolation
solutions.description: Deploy network micro-segmentation and enhanced monitoring specifically for legacy systems that cannot be immediately replaced
solutions.implementation: Implement network micro-segmentation to isolate legacy systems from general network. Deploy additional authentication layers for legacy system access. Restrict network communications to essential connections only using whitelist approach. Deploy specialized monitoring that compensates for system limitations (network-based rather than agent-based). Create comprehensive logging for all legacy system access and activities. Implement anomaly detection tuned for legacy system baseline behaviors.
solutions.technical_controls: Network segmentation technology, next-gen firewall rules, enhanced logging and SIEM integration, network-based monitoring

solutions.title: Knowledge Transfer Documentation Program
solutions.description: Establish mandatory documentation and cross-training requirements for all legacy systems
solutions.implementation: Create detailed runbooks for all legacy system operations including startup, shutdown, maintenance, and troubleshooting procedures. Require minimum of three staff members trained on each critical system. Implement regular knowledge verification testing to ensure documentation accuracy and staff competency. Include legacy system documentation in business continuity planning. Create mentorship program pairing legacy system experts with newer staff. Document tribal knowledge through structured interviews and shadowing programs.
solutions.technical_controls: Knowledge management system, competency tracking database, documentation templates, training completion tracking

solutions.title: Gradual Replacement Planning Process
solutions.description: Develop phased replacement methodology that treats system transitions as change management projects rather than technical cutover events
solutions.implementation: Create replacement methodology that includes stakeholder engagement planning beginning 18 months before transition. Implement parallel system operations during transition periods allowing gradual migration. Develop success metrics demonstrating replacement benefits while honoring legacy system contributions. Include psychological transition support recognizing emotional aspects of system change. Create communication strategy that addresses loss and change narratives. Provide training and support reducing competency anxiety about new systems.
solutions.technical_controls: Project management tools with change management workflows, parallel environment infrastructure, migration tracking systems

solutions.title: Executive Risk Dashboard
solutions.description: Create executive-level reporting that translates legacy system risks into business impact terms
solutions.implementation: Develop dashboard showing potential financial exposure from legacy system vulnerabilities. Include regulatory compliance risks and potential fines. Display business continuity threats from legacy system dependencies. Compare organizational legacy dependencies against industry peers and competitors. Calculate total cost of ownership including security incident risk, maintenance costs, and opportunity costs. Provide clear replacement investment ROI calculations. Update monthly with current risk posture and trend analysis.
solutions.technical_controls: Business intelligence dashboard, risk quantification tools, cost analysis system, automated reporting

solutions.title: Compensating Controls Framework
solutions.description: For legacy systems that cannot be immediately replaced, implement standardized compensating controls
solutions.implementation: Deploy enhanced backup procedures with offline, immutable backups for legacy systems. Implement isolated network segments with restricted access. Deploy additional access logging and monitoring compensating for system limitations. Create incident response procedures specific to legacy system compromises. Implement application-level firewalls or security wrappers around legacy applications. Document risk acceptance with clear accountability and review timelines. Establish compensating control audit procedures ensuring continued effectiveness.
solutions.technical_controls: Enhanced backup systems, network isolation technology, application security gateways, monitoring enhancement

risk_scenarios.title: Targeted Legacy Exploitation
risk_scenarios.description: Attackers scan for and specifically target known vulnerabilities in unsupported legacy systems, using them as initial compromise points. Organizations delay patching due to 'system stability' concerns, providing extended attack windows.
risk_scenarios.attack_vector: Automated scanning for legacy systems followed by exploitation of known, unpatched vulnerabilities
risk_scenarios.psychological_mechanism: Attachment-driven resistance to patching creates extended vulnerability windows despite public exploit availability
risk_scenarios.historical_example: WannaCry 2017 ransomware specifically targeted Windows XP systems that organizations kept operational past Microsoft's support end, causing widespread global impact

risk_scenarios.title: Vendor Impersonation Attacks
risk_scenarios.description: Threat actors impersonate legacy system vendors or support contractors, exploiting the trust and dependency relationships organizations have with these systems. Teams bypass normal security verification due to attachment to familiar vendor relationships.
risk_scenarios.attack_vector: Social engineering as legacy system vendor to gain access or deploy malicious updates
risk_scenarios.psychological_mechanism: Emotional dependency on legacy vendor relationships reduces verification behaviors
risk_scenarios.historical_example: Multiple incidents where attackers posed as legacy system support providers, gaining privileged access to organizations desperate for continued support of unsupported systems

risk_scenarios.title: Network Lateral Movement via Legacy Systems
risk_scenarios.description: Legacy systems often receive exemptions from network segmentation and monitoring, creating pathways for lateral movement after initial compromise. Attackers use trusted legacy systems to move through networks undetected, knowing security teams monitor these systems less rigorously.
risk_scenarios.attack_vector: Initial compromise followed by lateral movement through under-monitored legacy systems
risk_scenarios.psychological_mechanism: Attachment creates trust in legacy systems, reducing security monitoring and network segmentation
risk_scenarios.historical_example: Target 2013 breach where compromised HVAC vendor credentials provided access to legacy systems that lacked network segmentation from payment systems

risk_scenarios.title: Maintenance Window Exploitation
risk_scenarios.description: Attackers time attacks during extended maintenance windows when legacy systems are taken offline for updates, knowing that attachment-driven resistance creates infrequent, lengthy maintenance periods. Organizations may restore from outdated backups or skip security updates to minimize 'disruption' to beloved systems.
risk_scenarios.attack_vector: Compromise during infrequent maintenance windows when systems are vulnerable and monitoring is reduced
risk_scenarios.psychological_mechanism: Attachment minimizes maintenance frequency creating predictable vulnerability windows
risk_scenarios.historical_example: Industrial control system compromises during rare maintenance windows where systems were vulnerable and organizations rushed to restore operation without security verification
